Dear Mr. McKeage:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on . Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is
required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 899-6024.
Sincerely,
Barbara A Cote, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4113-1-h Employee records.
• (1)An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include

documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in
this rule:
• (h) A statement from the employee
regarding any convictions.
Two of five new employee files lacked a written statement from the employee
regarding their conviction.
CCI Rule 400.4155-1 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; initial treatment plan
• (1) The social service worker shall complete,
sign, and date an initial treatment plan for each
resident within 30 calendar days of admission.
One of six treatment plans reviewed was not completed in the required
timeframe. The plan was five days late.
Repeat Violation Established
2024 Interim dated 08/23/2024; CAP approved 09/19/2024
CCI Rule 400.4166-1-e Discharge plan
• (1) When a resident is discharged from
institutional care, all of the following information
shall be documented in the case record within
14 days after discharge:
• (e) A statement that the discharge plan
recommendations, including medical and
dental follow up that is needed, have
been reviewed with the resident and with
the parent and with the responsible case
manager.
Two of two discharge plans reviewed lacked information on future medical and/or
dental appointments.
CCI Rule 400.4535 Fire alarm

• (4) Fire alarm systems and devices in existing
facilities shall be maintained in proper working
order and shall continue to be approved until the
facility is remodeled or converted.
The annual fire alarm inspection was completed 01-07-2025. The inspection
found that 3 smoke detectors did not pass functional testing. Bay Pines is in the
process of replacing the detectors that were marked failed.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• R 400.4113 Employee records - Clarification was provided that interns need to
have all documentation a new hire employee would have in their HR file. CCI
rules define (h) “Child caring institution staff member” means an individual who
is 18 years or older, and to whom any of the following apply: (i) Is employed by
a child care institution for compensation, including adults who do not work
directly with children. (ii) Is a contract employee or self-employed individual
working with a child care institution. (iii) Is an intern or other person who
provides specific services under these rules.
• R 400.4150 (1) Incident Reporting. The rule was reviewed with administration
to notify the required individuals if a youth is hospitalized.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• The facility was provided information on what to do and what to report to
DCWL if an employee has a confirmed case with their own children.
• It was discussed with the facility the advantages of having staff sign and date
the job description when staff begin employment.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: 2024
Interim: Corrective action plan was recorded during this reporting period as a
result of the Interim Inspection completed on August 15, 2024. This CAP

contained one rule violation for Rule 400.4155 (1) Initial treatment plan, for one
treatment plan not being completed within the required timeframe. The facility
monitored treatment plans due dates more closely and re-assigned the treatment
plan to an available Group Leader if the assigned staff member was going to be
off on an extended leave. The facility completed the CAP action steps with no
noted concerns.
Financial Overview
N/A
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Bay Pines Center completed their most recent PREA audit on October 25, 2023,
and October 26, 2023. They were found in compliance with all applicable PREA
stands, and no corrective action plans were required. Bay Pine Center
participated in an annual PREA Compliance monitoring review on September 30,
2024, and was found to be compliant.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment was reviewed. Chief Administrator reported
that CAPs are consistently monitored and are fully completed. Chief Administrator
reported there were no barriers completing the CAPs. The facility implemented
MANDT restraint model and continues to reduce their restraint numbers.
Staff and Youth Interviews
The staff reported feeling supported, heard by administration and valued at the
facility. Staff were able to recognize and give examples of how the
facility/programming has grown over the years and how the environment has
become more positive for the youth and staff. Staff reported they have all the tools
they need to be successful at their job.
The youth all reported feeling safe, understanding the expectations of the program
and could identify at least one staff member they could talk to when feeling upset.
All of the youth reported having regular therapy, having enough food, getting their
medications and being busy with various groups or outings. None of the youth
voiced any concerns with the staff or the facility.
Description of Agency Walk Through

A walk through was completed on July 16, 2025. The facility was in good
condition with no safety concerns noted. The menu was posted, appropriate signs
displayed, and medication locked.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
